UNIT7

content:
Based on the provided context, the documents do not explicitly define "who" constitutes operational management.

However, the context does differentiate between "operational" and "administrative chains of command" (Source: airport_operations.pdf, Page 481) and mentions "operational versus administrative/functional expertise management" within a matrix management system (Source: airport_operations.pdf, Page 480). This suggests that operational management is a distinct management function focused on the operational aspects of the airport, separate from administrative or functional roles.

The text discusses "basic operational procedures of airports" (Source: airport_operations.pdf, Page 207) and "operational philosophies" in the terminal area, indicating areas where operational management would be focused. Senior airport management personnel are also mentioned in the context of handling emergencies (Source: airport_operations.pdf, Page 477), which would often involve operational aspects.

In summary, while the context clearly establishes the existence and distinction of operational management within the airport structure, it does not provide a specific definition of the individuals or roles that comprise it.

Although the basic operational procedures of airports as they relate to safety are generally
similar throughout the world, the manner in which those procedures are operated and the
organization used to effect them can differ quite radically. Perhaps nowhere in the airport
do the operational philosophies differ as much as in the terminal area. The two extreme

Organization (ISO) defines an EMS as a tool that enables an organization to
• Identify and control the environmental impact of its activities, products or
services, and to
• Improve its environmental performance continually, and to
• Implement a systematic approach to setting environmental objectives and
targets, to achieving these and to demonstrating that they have been achieved5

administrative/functional expertise management).
